ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  Vaaruni Eashwar
Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  There was only one Teaching Assistant

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  Vaaruni was really responsive over email, and in frequent communication with the class. Her feedback on class work was really helpful. She seemed like she really cared about being a good TF!
Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  Vaaruni was very knowledgeable about the course topic and extremely helpful! She was always available to answer any questions or provide feedback on the course.

Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  Vaaruni was a great TA. Although I never felt a need to meet with her one-on-one, she responded to emails promptly, posted all necessary materials to Canvas, provided helpful feedback for our final papers, and appeared to have a very professional and positive relationship with our professor, Kristin Reynolds. No complaints!
Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  Vaaruni did a great job. She was always really helpful in class, approachable, and extremely communicative and on top of emails and things on Canvas.

Instructor: Vaaruni Eashwar  Vaaruni was excellent in her management of the class. She organized the readings well and responded to queries promptly. I really appreciated her understanding and willingness to accommodate the students and her contributions in class discussions.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 15: I thought that we would get more course material/content about sustainable agriculture or environmental issues in food production, but that wasn't in the scope of the class.

Professor Reynolds was very knowledgable about the material, but sometimes dominated the conversation and came across as a bit cold. I found it hard to engage deeply in conversations with her continually interjecting with theory and clarification.

Regarding question 1 & 3 - the workload was pretty standard and the readings were fantastic - but the reading for this class was much heavier than some other courses - it might be average but it did seem like a lot
I think the first lesson would have benefitted from a course overview with a conceptual summary.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The readings more helpful than readings in most other classes I've taken, grad school AND undergrad. I liked the class discussions, and got a lot out of hearing other students' thoughts.
The readings were useful, and final presentations
The course did an excellent job of connecting heavy theoretical concepts to real-world problem and solutions. Additionally, the course covered a wide-range of topics and materials.

This class really expands our thinking and perspectives, a really valuable class not just for FES students or people in social justice and/or food systems, it covers so much nuance about social justice that it would be a valuable class for anyone to take - and our society would be far more functional if most people were aware of the principles and ideas of this class.

I really enjoyed class discussions. Kristin did a really good job of facilitating discussion, as well as seamlessly incorporating current events (such as the presidential election) into our conversations. My classmates were respectful, thoughtful, and reflective; even disagreements were enjoyable! The class could feel a bit long, as it meet for three hours straight on Thursday afternoons. However, there were plenty of weeks in which I felt completely engaged and lost track of time. Other highlights of the class include the topics covered (understanding social justice and its many faces/frameworks is so important!) and my classmates. As an undergraduate, it was wonderful to feel so welcomed by everyone. I learned just as much from my peers as I did from Kristin and the readings!
Readings were great. I liked how the class time was separated into different components, which kept me engaged. And the topics we discussed were so important and have been really formative for me.

Professor Reynolds was instrumental in creating a really safe and encouraging atmosphere in the class. This was crucial in facilitating discussions as she made it a point to acknowledge opinions. I especially appreciated her race sensitivity briefing as it gave students a framework to work within and allowed for better discussion.

For me, the readings were the most valuable, and the weekly readings responses. I think there was a good balance of theoretical readings and case studies, laid out in a logical progression that made it possible to understand the latter part of the semester.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Sometimes Kristin steered student discussion when I would have preferred we just let it go where it was going.
Group bonding
Integration of more interactive activities. Although I gained a lot from the discussions, I am a very hands on learner and would appreciate a wider range of in-classroom activities.

My main suggestion concerns workload. Although I really enjoyed writing reading responses and being forced to think about our readings critically, they were a pretty big time commitment. Perhaps 6-8 reading responses over the semester would be better than 10?
I think the course could be improved by spending less time having really theoretical or conceptual discussions, to discuss practical situations or the real world.
I think that the readings can be reduced a little, I appreciate the comprehensive reading list, but I do think that some readings could be listed as recommended.
Don't have students make weekly posts.

More flexibility in the final assignment would have been nice, as graduate students I'm not sure writing a 20 page paper directly related to theories learned in class is that helpful. Continuing an ongoing research project or preparing a research proposal would have been nice options. Reading responses should be max 250 words and should be entirely flexible.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A (all discussion)
It was effective and provided a good balance.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided me with a great theoretical and practical foundation for my understanding of the local and global food systems.

I am an undergraduate majoring in Environmental Studies. As my focus within EVST is food and agriculture, this class will count towards my concentration requirements and will definitely prove relevant as I conduct research for and write my thesis.

It has provided me with a good foundation in social justice theories and also provided an interdisciplinary approach to the topic. This gave it great depth and allows it to be applied to many different areas like political science, sociology and environmental studies.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about social justice issues in the food system and how to address these problems.

I took this class because of positive reviews from classmates and from my bosses at the Yale Sustainable Food Program; because of my personal interest in food, and a desire to learn more about social justice; and because of my interest in perhaps doing the 5th year MEM program at FES (this class allowed me to effectively test the waters).

I was interested in the food system and wanted to learn more. I was also interested in social justice and already thinking about how that relates to the environment and food. This course looked perfect--a way for me to explore interests I already had.
Because I have a keen interest in food politics and social justice issues and wanted to gain a better understanding of the field.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not really, I thought the focus of the class would be slightly different than it was.
Yes
Yes, I learned a lot from taking this course.
The knowledge I took away from this course WAY exceeded my expectations. Like, to another dimension.

Absolutely! I knew very little about social justice theory and frameworks going in; now I know a whole lot. While the class was a bit more theoretical than I realized it would be, it was absolutely worth it. I'll spend the rest of my life applying what I learned to real-life situations.
Yes! My understanding of the food system and social justice issues expanded so much in the past semester, and I'm so much more excited than I was to learn and work more in this field.
Yes, at times going beyond my expectations in its active relation to contemporary political issues.
Yes, I learned about social justice theory and how to look at issues in the food system through a number of theoretical lenses.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The team discussion project helped me understand that topic in a lot more depth. Thinking about questions and approaches to the material for the discussion helped me better critically read/understand later weeks' readings.
It was great to collaborate with peers from different schools and backgrounds. This was a very effective way to learn about social justice issues from a variety of vantage points.

The advantages to working in a group included bouncing ideas back and forth, sharing the work load, having other people to hold you accountable, and meeting some really cool folk. Disadvantages included logistics (finding times/places to meet), disagreements (albeit minor ones), and all of us feeling a bit lost at the beginning of the project.
We were able to provide varied input that enriched our reading of the text and our discussion with the class.

Advantages were less work, but disadvantages were that group members had vastly different backgrounds in the subject matter and couldn't come together in a single vision for what question we wanted our final project to answer.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Good for individuals from diverse backgrounds and previous level of engagement with social justice issues
I would highly recommend this course!
This course is eye-opening and you will be a better, more well-informed and aware person because of it. Try to keep up with the reading, they are so valuable

Do the readings plenty in advance (e.g. not the night before), and give yourself plenty of time to do them. You'll get more out of them that way! Also, if you're not used to three-hour seminars, bring caffeine and/or water and/or snacks. They'll come in handy.

I believe everyone should take this course, because it relates to everyone--you eat, so you are part of the food system whether you like it or not. Taking this course has been an incredibly valuable experience for me, and I recommend it to everyone. No matter what your field of study is,s you'll be surprised how it overlaps with this course.

I would advise spreading out the readings to be able to finish them before the reading response is due. I would also recommend starting to brainstorm the essay topic in advance to as to do adequate research. The lightning presentation should be practiced a few times to ensure a good delivery.
